title: Lackford Lakes Walking Route

images.title: Bob Jones / Lackford Lakes Nature Reserve
images.caption: Lackford Lakes Nature Reserve. Viewed from Bill Hide, one of several named bird hides on the Reserve.

images.title: Bob Jones / Egyptian geese at Lackford Lakes
images.caption: Egyptian geese at Lackford Lakes. These geese have just realised that some interlopers have grabbed their favourite spot and are running across a spit of land to oust them.

images.title: Bob Jones / Sailing clubhouse at Lackford
images.caption: Sailing clubhouse. The clubhouse for the St Edmundsbury Sailing and Canoeing Association (SESCA), at Lackford Lakes.

images.title: Bob Jones / Willow pollarding
images.caption: Willow pollarding. The Suffolk Wildlife Trust ensures that willow trees are managed in the traditional way. These willows will re-grow from the point at which they have been cut; in this case it is at eight to nine feet. The re-growth is vigorous and provides a fantastic habitat for a range of insects and nesting sites for birds. The ditch will also have increased sunlight, improving it for dragonflies and damselflies.

images.title: Bob Jones / Plover Lake, Lackford
images.caption: Plover Lake. One of the former gravel pits, now flooded, that form the Lackford Lakes Nature Reserve.

images.title: Bob Jones / Hanging out to dry
images.caption: Hanging out to dry. This cormorant is drying its wings, on a post in one of the former gravel pits. Behind, on a small island, are a number of canada geese and other birds.

images.title: Bob Jones / Track to Lackford Estate
images.caption: Track to Lackford Estate. This is a private track leading to the Lackford Estate, which is a large area of farmland between Lackford and Tuddenham. The photo is taken from the road between Cavenham and Lackford, which is part of the ancient Icknield Way.

description: This walk visits the pretty Lackford Lakes Nature Reserve near Bury St Edmunds in Suffolk. There's some pleasant walking trails taking you around a series of picturesque lakes with lot of wildlife to see. There's bird hides dotted around the site where you can look out for birds such as kingfisher, great crested grebe and tufted duck. There's good facilities too, with a free car park, cafe and visitor centre. The site sits right next to West Stow Country Park where you can enjoy more nice paths and visit the interesting West Stow Anglo-Saxon Village. There's also riverside trails along the long distance Lark Valley Path to try. Just north you'll find miles of peaceful woodland cycling and walking trails around the expansive King's Forest .
